title: Absolute privilege in English law
text:
Absolute privilege is a complete <a href="Defense%20%28legal%29">defence</a> to an action for <a href="English%20defamation%20law">defamation</a> in <a href="English%20law">English law</a>. If the defence of absolute privilege applies it is irrelevant that a defendant has acted with malice, knew information was false or acted solely to damage the reputation of the <a href="plaintiff">plaintiff</a>. Absolute privilege can be deployed in a narrow range of cases. Statements made in judicial proceedings are protected as are communications between a solicitor and their client. The <a href="Bill%20of%20Rights%201689">Bill of Rights of 1689</a> provides that proceedings of the <a href="Parliament%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Parliament of the United Kingdom</a> are also covered by absolute privilege.
Privileged statements.
Reports of court proceedings.

The defence under this section is excluded by section 8(6) of the <a href="Rehabilitation%20of%20Offenders%20Act%201974">Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974</a> (as amended by subsection (4) of this section). That is, reporting on proceedings relating to a spent offence is not privileged.
Section 14 replaces section 3 of the <a href="Law%20of%20Libel%20Amendment%20Act%201888">Law of Libel Amendment Act 1888</a> and section 8 of the <a href="Defamation%20Act%201952">Defamation Act 1952</a>. Subsection (3) was amended by the <a href="Defamation%20Act%202013">Defamation Act 2013</a>.
